changes.description: Runtime deprecation.
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

The fs.SyncWriteStream class was never intended to be a publicly accessible API. No alternative API is available. Please use a userland alternative.

modules.name: dep0062:_node_--debug

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

--debug activates the legacy V8 debugger interface, which was removed as of V8 5.8. It is replaced by Inspector which is activated with --inspect instead.

modules.name: dep0063:_serverresponse.prototype.writeheader()

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The http module ServerResponse.prototype.writeHeader() API is deprecated. Please use ServerResponse.prototype.writeHead() instead.

The ServerResponse.prototype.writeHeader() method was never documented as an officially supported API.

modules.name: dep0064:_tls.createsecurepair()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.
A deprecation code has been assigned.
Documentation-only deprecation.
Deprecation revoked.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

The tls.createSecurePair() API was deprecated in documentation in Node.js 0.11.3. Users should use tls.Socket instead.

modules.name: dep0065:_repl.repl_mode_magic_and_node_repl_mode=magic

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

The repl module's REPL_MODE_MAGIC constant, used for replMode option, has been removed. Its behavior has been functionally identical to that of REPL_MODE_SLOPPY since Node.js 6.0.0, when V8 5.0 was imported. Please use REPL_MODE_SLOPPY instead.

The NODE_REPL_MODE environment variable is used to set the underlying replMode of an interactive node session. Its value, magic, is also removed. Please use sloppy instead.

modules.name: dep0066:_outgoingmessage._headers,_outgoingmessage._headernames

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The http module outgoingMessage._headers and outgoingMessage._headerNames properties are deprecated. Use one of the public methods (e.g. outgoingMessage.getHeader(), outgoingMessage.getHeaders(), outgoingMessage.getHeaderNames(), outgoingMessage.hasHeader(), outgoingMessage.removeHeader(), outgoingMessage.setHeader()) for working with outgoing headers.

The outgoingMessage._headers and outgoingMessage._headerNames properties were never documented as officially supported properties.

modules.name: dep0067:_outgoingmessage.prototype._renderheaders

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The http module OutgoingMessage.prototype._renderHeaders() API is deprecated.

The OutgoingMessage.prototype._renderHeaders property was never documented as an officially supported API.

modules.name: dep0068:_node_debug

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

node debug corresponds to the legacy CLI debugger which has been replaced with a V8-inspector based CLI debugger available through node inspect.

modules.name: dep0069:_vm.runindebugcontext(string)

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

DebugContext has been removed in V8 and is not available in Node.js 10+.

DebugContext was an experimental API.

modules.name: dep0070:_async_hooks.currentid()

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

async_hooks.currentId() was renamed to async_hooks.executionAsyncId() for clarity.

This change was made while async_hooks was an experimental API.

modules.name: dep0071:_async_hooks.triggerid()

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

async_hooks.triggerId() was renamed to async_hooks.triggerAsyncId() for clarity.

This change was made while async_hooks was an experimental API.

modules.desc:

This change was made while async_hooks was an experimental API.

modules.textRaw: DEP0073: Several internal properties of net.Server
modules.name: dep0073:_several_internal_properties_of_net.server

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

Accessing several internal, undocumented properties of net.Server instances with inappropriate names is deprecated.

As the original API was undocumented and not generally useful for non-internal code, no replacement API is provided.
modules.displayName: DEP0073: Several internal properties of net.Server

modules.name: dep0074:_replserver.bufferedcommand

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

The REPLServer.bufferedCommand property was deprecated in favor of REPLServer.clearBufferedCommand().

modules.name: dep0075:_replserver.parsereplkeyword()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

REPLServer.parseREPLKeyword() was removed from userland visibility.

modules.name: dep0076:_tls.parsecertstring()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

tls.parseCertString() is a trivial parsing helper that was made public by mistake. This function can usually be replaced with:

const querystring = require('querystring');
querystring.parse(str, '\n', '=');

This function is not completely equivalent to querystring.parse(). One difference is that querystring.parse() does url decoding:

> querystring.parse('%E5%A5%BD=1', '\n', '=');
{ '好': '1' }
> tls.parseCertString('%E5%A5%BD=1');
{ '%E5%A5%BD': '1' }

modules.name: dep0077:_module._debug()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

Module._debug() is deprecated.

The Module._debug() function was never documented as an officially supported API.

modules.name: dep0078:_replserver.turnoffeditormode()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

REPLServer.turnOffEditorMode() was removed from userland visibility.

modules.textRaw: DEP0079: Custom inspection function on Objects via .inspect()
modules.name: dep0079:_custom_inspection_function_on_objects_via_.inspect()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

Using a property named inspect on an object to specify a custom inspection function for util.inspect() is deprecated. Use util.inspect.custom instead. For backward compatibility with Node.js prior to version 6.4.0, both may be specified.
modules.displayName: DEP0079: Custom inspection function on Objects via .inspect()

modules.name: dep0080:_path._makelong()

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The internal path._makeLong() was not intended for public use. However, userland modules have found it useful. The internal API is deprecated and replaced with an identical, public path.toNamespacedPath() method.

modules.textRaw: DEP0081: fs.truncate() using a file descriptor
modules.name: dep0081:_fs.truncate()_using_a_file_descriptor

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

fs.truncate() fs.truncateSync() usage with a file descriptor is deprecated. Please use fs.ftruncate() or fs.ftruncateSync() to work with file descriptors.
modules.displayName: DEP0081: fs.truncate() using a file descriptor

modules.name: dep0082:_replserver.prototype.memory()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

REPLServer.prototype.memory() is only necessary for the internal mechanics of the REPLServer itself. Do not use this function.

modules.textRaw: DEP0083: Disabling ECDH by setting ecdhCurve to false
modules.name: dep0083:_disabling_ecdh_by_setting_ecdhcurve_to_false

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life.

The ecdhCurve option to tls.createSecureContext() and tls.TLSSocket could be set to false to disable ECDH entirely on the server only. This mode was deprecated in preparation for migrating to OpenSSL 1.1.0 and consistency with the client and is now unsupported. Use the ciphers parameter instead.
modules.displayName: DEP0083: Disabling ECDH by setting ecdhCurve to false

modules.name: dep0084:_requiring_bundled_internal_dependencies

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

Since Node.js versions 4.4.0 and 5.2.0, several modules only intended for internal usage are mistakenly exposed to user code through require(). These modules are:

  • v8/tools/codemap
  • v8/tools/consarray
  • v8/tools/csvparser
  • v8/tools/logreader
  • v8/tools/profile_view
  • v8/tools/profile
  • v8/tools/SourceMap
  • v8/tools/splaytree
  • v8/tools/tickprocessor-driver
  • v8/tools/tickprocessor
  • node-inspect/lib/_inspect (from 7.6.0)
  • node-inspect/lib/internal/inspect_client (from 7.6.0)
  • node-inspect/lib/internal/inspect_repl (from 7.6.0)

The v8/* modules do not have any exports, and if not imported in a specific order would in fact throw errors. As such there are virtually no legitimate use cases for importing them through require().

On the other hand, node-inspect may be installed locally through a package manager, as it is published on the npm registry under the same name. No source code modification is necessary if that is done.

modules.name: dep0085:_asynchooks_sensitive_api

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

The AsyncHooks Sensitive API was never documented and had various minor issues. (See https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/15572.) Use the AsyncResource API instead.

modules.name: dep0086:_remove_runinasyncidscope

changes.description: End-of-Life.
Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

runInAsyncIdScope doesn't emit the 'before' or 'after' event and can thus cause a lot of issues. See https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/14328 for more details.

modules.name: dep0089:_require('assert')

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

Importing assert directly is not recommended as the exposed functions will use loose equality checks. Use require('assert').strict instead. The API is the same as the legacy assert but it will always use strict equality checks.

modules.textRaw: DEP0090: Invalid GCM authentication tag lengths
modules.name: dep0090:_invalid_gcm_authentication_tag_lengths

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

Node.js supports all GCM authentication tag lengths which are accepted by OpenSSL when calling decipher.setAuthTag(). This behavior will change in a future version at which point only authentication tag lengths of 128, 120, 112, 104, 96, 64, and 32 bits will be allowed. Authentication tags whose length is not included in this list will be considered invalid in compliance with NIST SP 800-38D.
modules.displayName: DEP0090: Invalid GCM authentication tag lengths

modules.name: dep0091:_crypto.default_encoding

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

The crypto.DEFAULT_ENCODING property is deprecated.

modules.name: dep0092:_top-level_`this`_bound_to_`module.exports`

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

Assigning properties to the top-level this as an alternative to module.exports is deprecated. Developers should use exports or module.exports instead.

modules.textRaw: DEP0093: crypto.fips is deprecated and replaced.
modules.name: dep0093:_crypto.fips_is_deprecated_and_replaced.

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The crypto.fips property is deprecated. Please use crypto.setFips() and crypto.getFips() instead.
modules.displayName: DEP0093: crypto.fips is deprecated and replaced.

modules.textRaw: DEP0094: Using `assert.fail()` with more than one argument.
modules.name: dep0094:_using_`assert.fail()`_with_more_than_one_argument.

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

Using assert.fail() with more than one argument is deprecated. Use assert.fail() with only one argument or use a different assert module method.
modules.displayName: DEP0094: Using `assert.fail()` with more than one argument.

modules.name: dep0095:_timers.enroll()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

timers.enroll() is deprecated. Please use the publicly documented setTimeout() or setInterval() instead.

modules.name: dep0096:_timers.unenroll()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

timers.unenroll() is deprecated. Please use the publicly documented clearTimeout() or clearInterval() instead.

modules.name: dep0097:_makecallback_with_domain_property

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

Users of MakeCallback that add the domain property to carry context, should start using the async_context variant of MakeCallback or CallbackScope, or the high-level AsyncResource class.

modules.textRaw: DEP0098: AsyncHooks Embedder AsyncResource.emitBefore and AsyncResource.emitAfter APIs
modules.name: dep0098:_asynchooks_embedder_asyncresource.emitbefore_and_asyncresource.emitafter_apis

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

The embedded API provided by AsyncHooks exposes .emitBefore() and .emitAfter() methods which are very easy to use incorrectly which can lead to unrecoverable errors.

Use asyncResource.runInAsyncScope() API instead which provides a much safer, and more convenient, alternative. See https://github.com/nodejs/node/pull/18513 for more details.
modules.displayName: DEP0098: AsyncHooks Embedder AsyncResource.emitBefore and AsyncResource.emitAfter APIs

modules.textRaw: DEP0099: async context-unaware node::MakeCallback C++ APIs
modules.name: dep0099:_async_context-unaware_node::makecallback_c++_apis

changes.description: Compile-time deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Compile-time

Certain versions of node::MakeCallback APIs available to native modules are deprecated. Please use the versions of the API that accept an async_context parameter.
modules.displayName: DEP0099: async context-unaware node::MakeCallback C++ APIs

modules.name: dep0100:_process.assert()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

process.assert() is deprecated. Please use the assert module instead.

This was never a documented feature.

modules.name: dep0101:_--with-lttng

changes.description: End-of-Life.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

The --with-lttng compile-time option has been removed.

modules.name: dep0102:_using_`noassert`_in_buffer#(read|write)_operations.

changes.description: End-of-Life.

modules.desc:
Type: End-of-Life

Using the noAssert argument has no functionality anymore. All input is going to be verified, no matter if it is set to true or not. Skipping the verification could lead to hard to find errors and crashes.

modules.name: dep0103:_process.binding('util').is[...]_typechecks

changes.description: Superseded by [DEP0111](#DEP0111).
Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only (supports --pending-deprecation)

Using process.binding() in general should be avoided. The type checking methods in particular can be replaced by using util.types.

This deprecation has been superseded by the deprecation of the process.binding() API (DEP0111).

modules.name: dep0104:_process.env_string_coercion

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only (supports --pending-deprecation)

When assigning a non-string property to process.env, the assigned value is implicitly converted to a string. This behavior is deprecated if the assigned value is not a string, boolean, or number. In the future, such assignment may result in a thrown error. Please convert the property to a string before assigning it to process.env.

modules.name: dep0105:_decipher.finaltol

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

decipher.finaltol() has never been documented and is currently an alias for decipher.final(). In the future, this API will likely be removed, and it is recommended to use decipher.final() instead.

modules.name: dep0106:_crypto.createcipher_and_crypto.createdecipher

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

Using crypto.createCipher() and crypto.createDecipher() should be avoided as they use a weak key derivation function (MD5 with no salt) and static initialization vectors. It is recommended to derive a key using crypto.pbkdf2() or crypto.scrypt() and to use crypto.createCipheriv() and crypto.createDecipheriv() to obtain the Cipher and Decipher objects respectively.

modules.name: dep0107:_tls.convertnpnprotocols()

changes.description: Runtime deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Runtime

This was an undocumented helper function not intended for use outside Node.js core and obsoleted by the removal of NPN (Next Protocol Negotiation) support.

modules.name: dep0108:_zlib.bytesread

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

Deprecated alias for zlib.bytesWritten. This original name was chosen because it also made sense to interpret the value as the number of bytes read by the engine, but is inconsistent with other streams in Node.js that expose values under these names.

modules.name: dep0110:_vm.script_cached_data

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The produceCachedData option is deprecated. Use script.createCachedData() instead.

modules.name: dep0111:_process.binding()

changes.description: Documentation-only deprecation.

modules.desc:
Type: Documentation-only

The process.binding() API is intended for use by Node.js internal code only. Use of process.binding() by userland code is unsupported.

miscs.name: esm
miscs.desc:
Node.js contains support for ES Modules based upon the Node.js EP for ES Modules.

Not all features of the EP are complete and will be landing as both VM support and implementation is ready. Error messages are still being polished.

miscs.name: Enabling
miscs.desc:
The --experimental-modules flag can be used to enable features for loading ESM modules.

Once this has been set, files ending with .mjs will be able to be loaded as ES Modules.

node --experimental-modules my-app.mjs

miscs.name: supported
miscs.desc: Only the CLI argument for the main entry point to the program can be an entry point into an ESM graph. Dynamic import can also be used to create entry points into ESM graphs at runtime.

properties.name: meta
properties.desc:
The import.meta metaproperty is an Object that contains the following property:

  • url <string> The absolute file: URL of the module.

miscs.name: unsupported
miscs.desc:
Feature Reason
require('./foo.mjs') ES Modules have differing resolution and timing, use dynamic import

modules.name: no_node_path
modules.desc: NODE_PATH is not part of resolving import specifiers. Please use symlinks if this behavior is desired.

modules.name: no_`require.extensions`
modules.desc: require.extensions is not used by import. The expectation is that loader hooks can provide this workflow in the future.

modules.name: no_`require.cache`
modules.desc: require.cache is not used by import. It has a separate cache.

modules.name: url_based_paths
modules.desc:
ESM are resolved and cached based upon URL semantics. This means that files containing special characters such as # and ? need to be escaped.

Modules will be loaded multiple times if the import specifier used to resolve them have a different query or fragment.

import './foo?query=1'; // loads ./foo with query of "?query=1"
import './foo?query=2'; // loads ./foo with query of "?query=2"

For now, only modules using the file: protocol can be loaded.

miscs.name: interop_with_existing_modules
miscs.desc:
All CommonJS, JSON, and C++ modules can be used with import.

Modules loaded this way will only be loaded once, even if their query or fragment string differs between import statements.

When loaded via import these modules will provide a single default export representing the value of module.exports at the time they finished evaluating.

// foo.js
module.exports = { one: 1 };

// bar.js
import foo from './foo.js';
foo.one === 1; // true

Builtin modules will provide named exports of their public API, as well as a default export which can be used for, among other things, modifying the named exports. Named exports of builtin modules are updated when the corresponding exports property is accessed, redefined, or deleted.

import EventEmitter from 'events';
const e = new EventEmitter();

import { readFile } from 'fs';
readFile('./foo.txt', (err, source) => {
  if (err) {
    console.error(err);
  } else {
    console.log(source);
  }
});

import fs, { readFileSync } from 'fs';

fs.readFileSync = () => Buffer.from('Hello, ESM');

fs.readFileSync === readFileSync;

miscs.name: Loader hooks
miscs.desc:
To customize the default module resolution, loader hooks can optionally be provided via a --loader ./loader-name.mjs argument to Node.js.

When hooks are used they only apply to ES module loading and not to any CommonJS modules loaded.

miscs.name: resolve_hook
miscs.desc:
The resolve hook returns the resolved file URL and module format for a given module specifier and parent file URL:

const baseURL = new URL('file://');
baseURL.pathname = `${process.cwd()}/`;

export async function resolve(specifier,
                              parentModuleURL = baseURL,
                              defaultResolver) {
  return {
    url: new URL(specifier, parentModuleURL).href,
    format: 'esm'
  };
}

The parentModuleURL is provided as undefined when performing main Node.js load itself.

The default Node.js ES module resolution function is provided as a third argument to the resolver for easy compatibility workflows.

In addition to returning the resolved file URL value, the resolve hook also returns a format property specifying the module format of the resolved module. This can be one of the following:

format Description
'esm' Load a standard JavaScript module
'cjs' Load a node-style CommonJS module
'builtin' Load a node builtin CommonJS module
'json' Load a JSON file
'addon' Load a C++ Addon
'dynamic' Use a dynamic instantiate hook

For example, a dummy loader to load JavaScript restricted to browser resolution rules with only JS file extension and Node.js builtin modules support could be written:

import path from 'path';
import process from 'process';
import Module from 'module';

const builtins = Module.builtinModules;
const JS_EXTENSIONS = new Set(['.js', '.mjs']);

const baseURL = new URL('file://');
baseURL.pathname = `${process.cwd()}/`;

export function resolve(specifier, parentModuleURL = baseURL, defaultResolve) {
  if (builtins.includes(specifier)) {
    return {
      url: specifier,
      format: 'builtin'
    };
  }
  if (/^\.{0,2}[/]/.test(specifier) !== true && !specifier.startsWith('file:')) {
    // For node_modules support:
    // return defaultResolve(specifier, parentModuleURL);
    throw new Error(
      `imports must begin with '/', './', or '../'; '${specifier}' does not`);
  }
  const resolved = new URL(specifier, parentModuleURL);
  const ext = path.extname(resolved.pathname);
  if (!JS_EXTENSIONS.has(ext)) {
    throw new Error(
      `Cannot load file with non-JavaScript file extension ${ext}.`);
  }
  return {
    url: resolved.href,
    format: 'esm'
  };
}

With this loader, running:

NODE_OPTIONS='--experimental-modules --loader ./custom-loader.mjs' node x.js

would load the module x.js as an ES module with relative resolution support (with node_modules loading skipped in this example).

miscs.name: dynamic_instantiate_hook
miscs.desc:
To create a custom dynamic module that doesn't correspond to one of the existing format interpretations, the dynamicInstantiate hook can be used. This hook is called only for modules that return format: 'dynamic' from the resolve hook.

export async function dynamicInstantiate(url) {
  return {
    exports: ['customExportName'],
    execute: (exports) => {
      // get and set functions provided for pre-allocated export names
      exports.customExportName.set('value');
    }
  };
}

With the list of module exports provided upfront, the execute function will then be called at the exact point of module evaluation order for that module in the import tree.

miscs.name: Errors
miscs.desc:
Applications running in Node.js will generally experience four categories of errors:

  • Standard JavaScript errors such as <EvalError>, <SyntaxError>, <RangeError>, <ReferenceError>, <TypeError>, and <URIError>.
  • System errors triggered by underlying operating system constraints such as attempting to open a file that does not exist or attempting to send data over a closed socket.
  • User-specified errors triggered by application code.
  • AssertionErrors are a special class of error that can be triggered when Node.js detects an exceptional logic violation that should never occur. These are raised typically by the assert module.

All JavaScript and System errors raised by Node.js inherit from, or are instances of, the standard JavaScript <Error> class and are guaranteed to provide at least the properties available on that class.

miscs.name: Error Propagation and Interception
miscs.desc:
Node.js supports several mechanisms for propagating and handling errors that occur while an application is running. How these errors are reported and handled depends entirely on the type of Error and the style of the API that is called.

All JavaScript errors are handled as exceptions that immediately generate and throw an error using the standard JavaScript throw mechanism. These are handled using the try…catch construct provided by the JavaScript language.

// Throws with a ReferenceError because z is undefined
try {
  const m = 1;
  const n = m + z;
} catch (err) {
  // Handle the error here.
}

Any use of the JavaScript throw mechanism will raise an exception that must be handled using try…catch or the Node.js process will exit immediately.

With few exceptions, Synchronous APIs (any blocking method that does not accept a callback function, such as fs.readFileSync), will use throw to report errors.

Errors that occur within Asynchronous APIs may be reported in multiple ways:

  • Most asynchronous methods that accept a callback function will accept an Error object passed as the first argument to that function. If that first argument is not null and is an instance of Error, then an error occurred that should be handled.
const fs = require('fs');
fs.readFile('a file that does not exist', (err, data) => {
  if (err) {
    console.error('There was an error reading the file!', err);
    return;
  }
  // Otherwise handle the data
});

  • When an asynchronous method is called on an object that is an EventEmitter, errors can be routed to that object's 'error' event.

    const net = require('net');
const connection = net.connect('localhost');

// Adding an 'error' event handler to a stream:
connection.on('error', (err) => {
  // If the connection is reset by the server, or if it can't
  // connect at all, or on any sort of error encountered by
  // the connection, the error will be sent here.
  console.error(err);
});

connection.pipe(process.stdout);

  • A handful of typically asynchronous methods in the Node.js API may still use the throw mechanism to raise exceptions that must be handled using try…catch. There is no comprehensive list of such methods; please refer to the documentation of each method to determine the appropriate error handling mechanism required.

The use of the 'error' event mechanism is most common for stream-based and event emitter-based APIs, which themselves represent a series of asynchronous operations over time (as opposed to a single operation that may pass or fail).

For all EventEmitter objects, if an 'error' event handler is not provided, the error will be thrown, causing the Node.js process to report an uncaught exception and crash unless either: The domain module is used appropriately or a handler has been registered for the 'uncaughtException' event.

const EventEmitter = require('events');
const ee = new EventEmitter();

setImmediate(() => {
  // This will crash the process because no 'error' event
  // handler has been added.
  ee.emit('error', new Error('This will crash'));
});

Errors generated in this way cannot be intercepted using try…catch as they are thrown after the calling code has already exited.

Developers must refer to the documentation for each method to determine exactly how errors raised by those methods are propagated.

miscs.name: Error-first callbacks
miscs.desc:
Most asynchronous methods exposed by the Node.js core API follow an idiomatic pattern referred to as an error-first callback. With this pattern, a callback function is passed to the method as an argument. When the operation either completes or an error is raised, the callback function is called with the Error object (if any) passed as the first argument. If no error was raised, the first argument will be passed as null.

const fs = require('fs');

function errorFirstCallback(err, data) {
  if (err) {
    console.error('There was an error', err);
    return;
  }
  console.log(data);
}

fs.readFile('/some/file/that/does-not-exist', errorFirstCallback);
fs.readFile('/some/file/that/does-exist', errorFirstCallback);

The JavaScript try…catch mechanism cannot be used to intercept errors generated by asynchronous APIs. A common mistake for beginners is to try to use throw inside an error-first callback:

// THIS WILL NOT WORK:
const fs = require('fs');

try {
  fs.readFile('/some/file/that/does-not-exist', (err, data) => {
    // mistaken assumption: throwing here...
    if (err) {
      throw err;
    }
  });
} catch (err) {
  // This will not catch the throw!
  console.error(err);
}

This will not work because the callback function passed to fs.readFile() is called asynchronously. By the time the callback has been called, the surrounding code (including the try { } catch (err) { } block will have already exited. Throwing an error inside the callback can crash the Node.js process in most cases. If domains are enabled, or a handler has been registered with process.on('uncaughtException'), such errors can be intercepted.

miscs.name: Exceptions vs. Errors
miscs.desc:
A JavaScript exception is a value that is thrown as a result of an invalid operation or as the target of a throw statement. While it is not required that these values are instances of Error or classes which inherit from Error, all exceptions thrown by Node.js or the JavaScript runtime will be instances of Error.

Some exceptions are unrecoverable at the JavaScript layer. Such exceptions will always cause the Node.js process to crash. Examples include assert() checks or abort() calls in the C++ layer.

miscs.name: system_errors
miscs.desc:
Node.js generates system errors when exceptions occur within its runtime environment. These usually occur when an application violates an operating system constraint. For example, a system error will occur if an application attempts to read a file that does not exist.

System errors are usually generated at the syscall level. For a comprehensive list, see the errno(3) man page.

In Node.js, system errors are Error objects with extra properties.

classes.name: SystemError
classes.desc:
• address <string> If present, the address to which a network connection failed
  • code <string> The string error code
  • dest <string> If present, the file path destination when reporting a file system error
  • errno <number> | <string> The system-provided error number
  • info <Object> If present, extra details about the error condition
  • message <string> A system-provided human-readable description of the error
  • path <string> If present, the file path when reporting a file system error
  • port <number> If present, the network connection port that is not available
  • syscall <string> The name of the system call that triggered the error

properties.name: address
properties.desc: If present, error.address is a string describing the address to which a network connection failed.

properties.name: code
properties.desc: The error.code property is a string representing the error code.

properties.name: dest
properties.desc: If present, error.dest is the file path destination when reporting a file system error.

properties.name: errno
properties.desc: The error.errno property is a number or a string. If it is a number, it is a negative value which corresponds to the error code defined in libuv Error handling. See the libuv errno.h header file (deps/uv/include/uv/errno.h in the Node.js source tree) for details. In case of a string, it is the same as error.code.

properties.name: info
properties.desc: If present, error.info is an object with details about the error condition.

properties.name: message
properties.desc: error.message is a system-provided human-readable description of the error.

properties.name: path
properties.desc: If present, error.path is a string containing a relevant invalid pathname.

properties.name: port
properties.desc: If present, error.port is the network connection port that is not available.

properties.name: syscall
properties.desc: The error.syscall property is a string describing the syscall that failed.

modules.name: common_system_errors
modules.desc:
This is a list of system errors commonly-encountered when writing a Node.js program. For a comprehensive list, see the errno(3) man page.

  • EACCES (Permission denied): An attempt was made to access a file in a way forbidden by its file access permissions.

  • EADDRINUSE (Address already in use): An attempt to bind a server (net, http, or https) to a local address failed due to another server on the local system already occupying that address.

  • ECONNREFUSED (Connection refused): No connection could be made because the target machine actively refused it. This usually results from trying to connect to a service that is inactive on the foreign host.

  • ECONNRESET (Connection reset by peer): A connection was forcibly closed by a peer. This normally results from a loss of the connection on the remote socket due to a timeout or reboot. Commonly encountered via the http and net modules.

  • EEXIST (File exists): An existing file was the target of an operation that required that the target not exist.

  • EISDIR (Is a directory): An operation expected a file, but the given pathname was a directory.

  • EMFILE (Too many open files in system): Maximum number of file descriptors allowable on the system has been reached, and requests for another descriptor cannot be fulfilled until at least one has been closed. This is encountered when opening many files at once in parallel, especially on systems (in particular, macOS) where there is a low file descriptor limit for processes. To remedy a low limit, run ulimit -n 2048 in the same shell that will run the Node.js process.

  • ENOENT (No such file or directory): Commonly raised by fs operations to indicate that a component of the specified pathname does not exist — no entity (file or directory) could be found by the given path.

  • ENOTDIR (Not a directory): A component of the given pathname existed, but was not a directory as expected. Commonly raised by fs.readdir.

  • ENOTEMPTY (Directory not empty): A directory with entries was the target of an operation that requires an empty directory — usually fs.unlink.

  • EPERM (Operation not permitted): An attempt was made to perform an operation that requires elevated privileges.

  • EPIPE (Broken pipe): A write on a pipe, socket, or FIFO for which there is no process to read the data. Commonly encountered at the net and http layers, indicative that the remote side of the stream being written to has been closed.

  • ETIMEDOUT (Operation timed out): A connect or send request failed because the connected party did not properly respond after a period of time. Usually encountered by http or net — often a sign that a socket.end() was not properly called.

miscs.name: node.js_error_codes

modules.name: err_ambiguous_argument
modules.desc: A function argument is being used in a way that suggests that the function signature may be misunderstood. This is thrown by the assert module when the message parameter in assert.throws(block, message) matches the error message thrown by block because that usage suggests that the user believes message is the expected message rather than the message the AssertionError will display if block does not throw.

modules.name: err_arg_not_iterable
modules.desc: An iterable argument (i.e. a value that works with for...of loops) was required, but not provided to a Node.js API.

modules.name: err_assertion
modules.desc: A special type of error that can be triggered whenever Node.js detects an exceptional logic violation that should never occur. These are raised typically by the assert module.

modules.name: err_async_callback
modules.desc: An attempt was made to register something that is not a function as an AsyncHooks callback.

modules.name: err_async_type
modules.desc: The type of an asynchronous resource was invalid. Note that users are also able to define their own types if using the public embedder API.

modules.name: err_buffer_out_of_bounds
modules.desc: An operation outside the bounds of a Buffer was attempted.

modules.name: err_buffer_too_large
modules.desc: An attempt has been made to create a Buffer larger than the maximum allowed size.

modules.name: err_cannot_transfer_object
modules.desc: The value passed to postMessage() contained an object that is not supported for transferring.

modules.name: err_cannot_watch_sigint
modules.desc: Node.js was unable to watch for the SIGINT signal.

modules.name: err_child_closed_before_reply
modules.desc: A child process was closed before the parent received a reply.

modules.name: err_child_process_ipc_required
modules.desc: Used when a child process is being forked without specifying an IPC channel.

modules.name: err_child_process_stdio_maxbuffer
modules.desc: Used when the main process is trying to read data from the child process's STDERR/STDOUT, and the data's length is longer than the maxBuffer option.

modules.name: err_closed_message_port
modules.desc: There was an attempt to use a MessagePort instance in a closed state, usually after .close() has been called.

modules.name: err_console_writable_stream
modules.desc: Console was instantiated without stdout stream, or Console has a non-writable stdout or stderr stream.

modules.name: err_construct_call_required
modules.desc: A constructor for a class was called without new.

modules.name: err_cpu_usage
modules.desc: The native call from process.cpuUsage could not be processed.

modules.name: err_crypto_custom_engine_not_supported
modules.desc: A client certificate engine was requested that is not supported by the version of OpenSSL being used.

modules.name: err_crypto_ecdh_invalid_format
modules.desc: An invalid value for the format argument was passed to the crypto.ECDH() class getPublicKey() method.

modules.name: err_crypto_ecdh_invalid_public_key
modules.desc: An invalid value for the key argument has been passed to the crypto.ECDH() class computeSecret() method. It means that the public key lies outside of the elliptic curve.

modules.name: err_crypto_engine_unknown
modules.desc: An invalid crypto engine identifier was passed to require('crypto').setEngine().

modules.name: err_crypto_fips_forced
modules.desc: The --force-fips command-line argument was used but there was an attempt to enable or disable FIPS mode in the crypto module.

modules.name: err_crypto_fips_unavailable
modules.desc: An attempt was made to enable or disable FIPS mode, but FIPS mode was not available.

modules.name: err_crypto_hash_digest_no_utf16
modules.desc: The UTF-16 encoding was used with hash.digest(). While the hash.digest() method does allow an encoding argument to be passed in, causing the method to return a string rather than a Buffer, the UTF-16 encoding (e.g. ucs or utf16le) is not supported.

modules.name: err_crypto_hash_finalized
modules.desc: hash.digest() was called multiple times. The hash.digest() method must be called no more than one time per instance of a Hash object.

modules.name: err_crypto_hash_update_failed
modules.desc: hash.update() failed for any reason. This should rarely, if ever, happen.

modules.name: err_crypto_incompatible_key_options
modules.desc: The selected public or private key encoding is incompatible with other options.

modules.name: err_crypto_invalid_digest
modules.desc: An invalid crypto digest algorithm was specified.

modules.name: err_crypto_invalid_state
modules.desc: A crypto method was used on an object that was in an invalid state. For instance, calling cipher.getAuthTag() before calling cipher.final().

modules.name: err_crypto_pbkdf2_error
modules.desc: The PBKDF2 algorithm failed for unspecified reasons. OpenSSL does not provide more details and therefore neither does Node.js.

modules.name: err_crypto_scrypt_invalid_parameter
modules.desc: One or more crypto.scrypt() or crypto.scryptSync() parameters are outside their legal range.

modules.name: err_crypto_scrypt_not_supported
modules.desc: Node.js was compiled without scrypt support. Not possible with the official release binaries but can happen with custom builds, including distro builds.

modules.name: err_crypto_sign_key_required
modules.desc: A signing key was not provided to the sign.sign() method.

modules.name: err_crypto_timing_safe_equal_length
modules.desc: crypto.timingSafeEqual() was called with Buffer, TypedArray, or DataView arguments of different lengths.

modules.name: err_dns_set_servers_failed
modules.desc: c-ares failed to set the DNS server.

modules.name: err_domain_callback_not_available
modules.desc: The domain module was not usable since it could not establish the required error handling hooks, because process.setUncaughtExceptionCaptureCallback() had been called at an earlier point in time.

modules.name: err_domain_cannot_set_uncaught_exception_capture
modules.desc:
process.setUncaughtExceptionCaptureCallback() could not be called because the domain module has been loaded at an earlier point in time.

The stack trace is extended to include the point in time at which the domain module had been loaded.

modules.name: err_encoding_invalid_encoded_data
modules.desc: Data provided to util.TextDecoder() API was invalid according to the encoding provided.

modules.name: err_encoding_not_supported
modules.desc: Encoding provided to util.TextDecoder() API was not one of the WHATWG Supported Encodings.

modules.name: err_falsy_value_rejection
modules.desc: A Promise that was callbackified via util.callbackify() was rejected with a falsy value.

modules.name: err_fs_file_too_large
modules.desc: An attempt has been made to read a file whose size is larger than the maximum allowed size for a Buffer.

modules.name: err_fs_invalid_symlink_type
modules.desc: An invalid symlink type was passed to the fs.symlink() or fs.symlinkSync() methods.

modules.name: err_http_headers_sent
modules.desc: An attempt was made to add more headers after the headers had already been sent.

modules.name: err_http_invalid_header_value
modules.desc: An invalid HTTP header value was specified.

modules.name: err_http_invalid_status_code
modules.desc: Status code was outside the regular status code range (100-999).

modules.name: err_http_trailer_invalid
modules.desc: The Trailer header was set even though the transfer encoding does not support that.

modules.name: err_http2_altsvc_invalid_origin
modules.desc: HTTP/2 ALTSVC frames require a valid origin.

modules.name: err_http2_altsvc_length
modules.desc: HTTP/2 ALTSVC frames are limited to a maximum of 16,382 payload bytes.

modules.name: err_http2_connect_authority
modules.desc: For HTTP/2 requests using the CONNECT method, the :authority pseudo-header is required.

modules.name: err_http2_connect_path
modules.desc: For HTTP/2 requests using the CONNECT method, the :path pseudo-header is forbidden.

modules.name: err_http2_connect_scheme
modules.desc: For HTTP/2 requests using the CONNECT method, the :scheme pseudo-header is forbidden.

modules.name: err_http2_error
modules.desc: A non-specific HTTP/2 error has occurred.

modules.name: err_http2_goaway_session
modules.desc: New HTTP/2 Streams may not be opened after the Http2Session has received a GOAWAY frame from the connected peer.

modules.name: err_http2_headers_after_respond
modules.desc: An additional headers was specified after an HTTP/2 response was initiated.

modules.name: err_http2_headers_sent
modules.desc: An attempt was made to send multiple response headers.

modules.name: err_http2_header_single_value
modules.desc: Multiple values were provided for an HTTP/2 header field that was required to have only a single value.

modules.name: err_http2_info_status_not_allowed
modules.desc: Informational HTTP status codes (1xx) may not be set as the response status code on HTTP/2 responses.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_connection_headers
modules.desc: HTTP/1 connection specific headers are forbidden to be used in HTTP/2 requests and responses.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_header_value
modules.desc: An invalid HTTP/2 header value was specified.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_info_status
modules.desc: An invalid HTTP informational status code has been specified. Informational status codes must be an integer between 100 and 199 (inclusive).

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_origin
modules.desc: HTTP/2 ORIGIN frames require a valid origin.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_packed_settings_length
modules.desc: Input Buffer and Uint8Array instances passed to the http2.getUnpackedSettings() API must have a length that is a multiple of six.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_pseudoheader
modules.desc: Only valid HTTP/2 pseudoheaders (:status, :path, :authority, :scheme, and :method) may be used.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_session
modules.desc: An action was performed on an Http2Session object that had already been destroyed.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_setting_value
modules.desc: An invalid value has been specified for an HTTP/2 setting.

modules.name: err_http2_invalid_stream
modules.desc: An operation was performed on a stream that had already been destroyed.

modules.name: err_http2_max_pending_settings_ack
modules.desc: Whenever an HTTP/2 SETTINGS frame is sent to a connected peer, the peer is required to send an acknowledgment that it has received and applied the new SETTINGS. By default, a maximum number of unacknowledged SETTINGS frames may be sent at any given time. This error code is used when that limit has been reached.

modules.name: err_http2_nested_push
modules.desc: An attempt was made to initiate a new push stream from within a push stream. Nested push streams are not permitted.

modules.name: err_http2_no_socket_manipulation
modules.desc: An attempt was made to directly manipulate (read, write, pause, resume, etc.) a socket attached to an Http2Session.

modules.name: err_http2_origin_length
modules.desc: HTTP/2 ORIGIN frames are limited to a length of 16382 bytes.

modules.name: err_http2_out_of_streams
modules.desc: The number of streams created on a single HTTP/2 session reached the maximum limit.

modules.name: err_http2_payload_forbidden
modules.desc: A message payload was specified for an HTTP response code for which a payload is forbidden.

modules.name: err_http2_ping_cancel
modules.desc: An HTTP/2 ping was canceled.

modules.name: err_http2_ping_length
modules.desc: HTTP/2 ping payloads must be exactly 8 bytes in length.

modules.name: err_http2_pseudoheader_not_allowed
modules.desc: An HTTP/2 pseudo-header has been used inappropriately. Pseudo-headers are header key names that begin with the : prefix.

modules.name: err_http2_push_disabled
modules.desc: An attempt was made to create a push stream, which had been disabled by the client.

modules.name: err_http2_send_file
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use the Http2Stream.prototype.responseWithFile() API to send a directory.

modules.name: err_http2_send_file_noseek
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use the Http2Stream.prototype.responseWithFile() API to send something other than a regular file, but offset or length options were provided.

modules.name: err_http2_session_error
modules.desc: The Http2Session closed with a non-zero error code.

modules.name: err_http2_settings_cancel
modules.desc: The Http2Session settings canceled.

modules.name: err_http2_socket_bound
modules.desc: An attempt was made to connect a Http2Session object to a net.Socket or tls.TLSSocket that had already been bound to another Http2Session object.

modules.name: err_http2_socket_unbound
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use the socket property of an Http2Session that has already been closed.

modules.name: err_http2_status_101
modules.desc: Use of the 101 Informational status code is forbidden in HTTP/2.

modules.name: err_http2_status_invalid
modules.desc: An invalid HTTP status code has been specified. Status codes must be an integer between 100 and 599 (inclusive).

modules.name: err_http2_stream_cancel
modules.desc: An Http2Stream was destroyed before any data was transmitted to the connected peer.

modules.name: err_http2_stream_error
modules.desc: A non-zero error code was been specified in an RST_STREAM frame.

modules.name: err_http2_stream_self_dependency
modules.desc: When setting the priority for an HTTP/2 stream, the stream may be marked as a dependency for a parent stream. This error code is used when an attempt is made to mark a stream and dependent of itself.

modules.name: err_http2_trailers_already_sent
modules.desc: Trailing headers have already been sent on the Http2Stream.

modules.name: err_http2_trailers_not_ready
modules.desc: The http2stream.sendTrailers() method cannot be called until after the 'wantTrailers' event is emitted on an Http2Stream object. The 'wantTrailers' event will only be emitted if the waitForTrailers option is set for the Http2Stream.

modules.name: err_http2_unsupported_protocol
modules.desc: http2.connect() was passed a URL that uses any protocol other than http: or https:.

modules.name: err_index_out_of_range
modules.desc: A given index was out of the accepted range (e.g. negative offsets).

modules.name: err_inspector_already_connected
modules.desc: While using the inspector module, an attempt was made to connect when the inspector was already connected.

modules.name: err_inspector_closed
modules.desc: While using the inspector module, an attempt was made to use the inspector after the session had already closed.

modules.name: err_inspector_not_available
modules.desc: The inspector module is not available for use.

modules.name: err_inspector_not_connected
modules.desc: While using the inspector module, an attempt was made to use the inspector before it was connected.

modules.name: err_invalid_address_family
modules.desc: The provided address family is not understood by the Node.js API.

modules.name: err_invalid_arg_type
modules.desc: An argument of the wrong type was passed to a Node.js API.

modules.name: err_invalid_arg_value
modules.desc: An invalid or unsupported value was passed for a given argument.

modules.name: err_invalid_array_length
modules.desc: An array was not of the expected length or in a valid range.

modules.name: err_invalid_async_id
modules.desc: An invalid asyncId or triggerAsyncId was passed using AsyncHooks. An id less than -1 should never happen.

modules.name: err_invalid_buffer_size
modules.desc: A swap was performed on a Buffer but its size was not compatible with the operation.

modules.name: err_invalid_callback
modules.desc: A callback function was required but was not been provided to a Node.js API.

modules.name: err_invalid_char
modules.desc: Invalid characters were detected in headers.

modules.name: err_invalid_cursor_pos
modules.desc: A cursor on a given stream cannot be moved to a specified row without a specified column.

modules.name: err_invalid_domain_name
modules.desc: hostname can not be parsed from a provided URL.

modules.name: err_invalid_fd
modules.desc: A file descriptor ('fd') was not valid (e.g. it was a negative value).

modules.name: err_invalid_fd_type
modules.desc: A file descriptor ('fd') type was not valid.

modules.name: err_invalid_file_url_host
modules.desc: A Node.js API that consumes file: URLs (such as certain functions in the fs module) encountered a file URL with an incompatible host. This situation can only occur on Unix-like systems where only localhost or an empty host is supported.

modules.name: err_invalid_file_url_path
modules.desc: A Node.js API that consumes file: URLs (such as certain functions in the fs module) encountered a file URL with an incompatible path. The exact semantics for determining whether a path can be used is platform-dependent.

modules.name: err_invalid_handle_type
modules.desc: An attempt was made to send an unsupported "handle" over an IPC communication channel to a child process. See subprocess.send() and process.send() for more information.

modules.name: err_invalid_http_token
modules.desc: An invalid HTTP token was supplied.

modules.name: err_invalid_ip_address
modules.desc: An IP address is not valid.

modules.name: err_invalid_opt_value
modules.desc: An invalid or unexpected value was passed in an options object.

modules.name: err_invalid_opt_value_encoding
modules.desc: An invalid or unknown file encoding was passed.

modules.name: err_invalid_performance_mark
modules.desc: While using the Performance Timing API (perf_hooks), a performance mark is invalid.

modules.name: err_invalid_protocol
modules.desc: An invalid options.protocol was passed.

modules.name: err_invalid_repl_eval_config
modules.desc: Both breakEvalOnSigint and eval options were set in the REPL config, which is not supported.

modules.name: err_invalid_return_property
modules.desc: Thrown in case a function option does not provide a valid value for one of its returned object properties on execution.

modules.name: err_invalid_return_property_value
modules.desc: Thrown in case a function option does not provide an expected value type for one of its returned object properties on execution.

modules.name: err_invalid_return_value
modules.desc: Thrown in case a function option does not return an expected value type on execution, such as when a function is expected to return a promise.

modules.name: err_invalid_sync_fork_input
modules.desc: A Buffer, TypedArray, DataView or string was provided as stdio input to an asynchronous fork. See the documentation for the child_process module for more information.

modules.name: err_invalid_this
modules.desc:
A Node.js API function was called with an incompatible this value.

const urlSearchParams = new URLSearchParams('foo=bar&baz=new');

const buf = Buffer.alloc(1);
urlSearchParams.has.call(buf, 'foo');
// Throws a TypeError with code 'ERR_INVALID_THIS'

modules.name: err_invalid_transfer_object
modules.desc: An invalid transfer object was passed to postMessage().

modules.name: err_invalid_tuple
modules.desc: An element in the iterable provided to the WHATWG URLSearchParams constructor did not represent a [name, value] tuple – that is, if an element is not iterable, or does not consist of exactly two elements.

modules.name: err_invalid_uri
modules.desc: An invalid URI was passed.

modules.name: err_invalid_url
modules.desc: An invalid URL was passed to the WHATWG URL constructor to be parsed. The thrown error object typically has an additional property 'input' that contains the URL that failed to parse.

modules.name: err_invalid_url_scheme
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use a URL of an incompatible scheme (protocol) for a specific purpose. It is only used in the WHATWG URL API support in the fs module (which only accepts URLs with 'file' scheme), but may be used in other Node.js APIs as well in the future.

modules.name: err_ipc_channel_closed
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use an IPC communication channel that was already closed.

modules.name: err_ipc_disconnected
modules.desc: An attempt was made to disconnect an IPC communication channel that was already disconnected. See the documentation for the child_process module for more information.

modules.name: err_ipc_one_pipe
modules.desc: An attempt was made to create a child Node.js process using more than one IPC communication channel. See the documentation for the child_process module for more information.

modules.name: err_ipc_sync_fork
modules.desc: An attempt was made to open an IPC communication channel with a synchronously forked Node.js process. See the documentation for the child_process module for more information.

modules.name: err_memory_allocation_failed
modules.desc: An attempt was made to allocate memory (usually in the C++ layer) but it failed.

modules.name: err_method_not_implemented
modules.desc: A method is required but not implemented.

modules.name: err_missing_args
modules.desc: A required argument of a Node.js API was not passed. This is only used for strict compliance with the API specification (which in some cases may accept func(undefined) but not func()). In most native Node.js APIs, func(undefined) and func() are treated identically, and the ERR_INVALID_ARG_TYPE error code may be used instead.

modules.name: err_missing_dynamic_instantiate_hook
modules.desc: An ES6 module loader hook specified format: 'dynamic' but did not provide a dynamicInstantiate hook.

modules.name: err_missing_message_port_in_transfer_list
modules.desc: A MessagePort was found in the object passed to a postMessage() call, but not provided in the transferList for that call.

modules.name: err_missing_module
modules.desc: An ES6 module could not be resolved.

modules.name: err_missing_platform_for_worker
modules.desc: The V8 platform used by this instance of Node.js does not support creating Workers. This is caused by lack of embedder support for Workers. In particular, this error will not occur with standard builds of Node.js.

modules.name: err_module_resolution_legacy
modules.desc: A failure occurred resolving imports in an ES6 module.

modules.name: err_multiple_callback
modules.desc:
A callback was called more than once.

A callback is almost always meant to only be called once as the query can either be fulfilled or rejected but not both at the same time. The latter would be possible by calling a callback more than once.

modules.name: err_napi_cons_function
modules.desc: While using N-API, a constructor passed was not a function.

modules.name: err_napi_invalid_dataview_args
modules.desc: While calling napi_create_dataview(), a given offset was outside the bounds of the dataview or offset + length was larger than a length of given buffer.

modules.name: err_napi_invalid_typedarray_alignment
modules.desc: While calling napi_create_typedarray(), the provided offset was not a multiple of the element size.

modules.name: err_napi_invalid_typedarray_length
modules.desc: While calling napi_create_typedarray(), (length * size_of_element) + byte_offset was larger than the length of given buffer.

modules.name: err_napi_tsfn_call_js
modules.desc: An error occurred while invoking the JavaScript portion of the thread-safe function.

modules.name: err_napi_tsfn_get_undefined
modules.desc: An error occurred while attempting to retrieve the JavaScript undefined value.

modules.name: err_napi_tsfn_start_idle_loop
modules.desc: On the main thread, values are removed from the queue associated with the thread-safe function in an idle loop. This error indicates that an error has occurred when attempting to start the loop.

modules.name: err_napi_tsfn_stop_idle_loop
modules.desc: Once no more items are left in the queue, the idle loop must be suspended. This error indicates that the idle loop has failed to stop.

modules.name: err_no_crypto
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use crypto features while Node.js was not compiled with OpenSSL crypto support.

modules.name: err_no_icu
modules.desc: An attempt was made to use features that require ICU, but Node.js was not compiled with ICU support.

modules.name: err_no_longer_supported
modules.desc: A Node.js API was called in an unsupported manner, such as Buffer.write(string, encoding, offset[, length]).

modules.name: err_out_of_range
modules.desc: A given value is out of the accepted range.

modules.name: err_require_esm
modules.desc: An attempt was made to require() an ES6 module.

modules.name: err_script_execution_interrupted
modules.desc: Script execution was interrupted by SIGINT (For example, when Ctrl+C was pressed).

modules.name: err_server_already_listen
modules.desc: The server.listen() method was called while a net.Server was already listening. This applies to all instances of net.Server, including HTTP, HTTPS, and HTTP/2 Server instances.

modules.name: err_server_not_running
modules.desc: The server.close() method was called when a net.Server was not running. This applies to all instances of net.Server, including HTTP, HTTPS, and HTTP/2 Server instances.

modules.name: err_socket_already_bound
modules.desc: An attempt was made to bind a socket that has already been bound.

modules.name: err_socket_bad_buffer_size
modules.desc: An invalid (negative) size was passed for either the recvBufferSize or sendBufferSize options in dgram.createSocket().

modules.name: err_socket_bad_port
modules.desc: An API function expecting a port >= 0 and < 65536 received an invalid value.

modules.name: err_socket_bad_type
modules.desc: An API function expecting a socket type (udp4 or udp6) received an invalid value.

modules.name: err_socket_buffer_size
modules.desc: While using dgram.createSocket(), the size of the receive or send Buffer could not be determined.

modules.name: err_socket_cannot_send
modules.desc: Data could be sent on a socket.

modules.name: err_socket_closed
modules.desc: An attempt was made to operate on an already closed socket.

modules.name: err_socket_dgram_not_running
modules.desc: A call was made and the UDP subsystem was not running.

modules.name: err_stream_cannot_pipe
modules.desc: An attempt was made to call stream.pipe() on a Writable stream.

modules.name: err_stream_destroyed
modules.desc: A stream method was called that cannot complete because the stream was destroyed using stream.destroy().

modules.name: err_stream_null_values
modules.desc: An attempt was made to call stream.write() with a null chunk.

modules.name: err_stream_premature_close
modules.desc: An error returned by stream.finished() and stream.pipeline(), when a stream or a pipeline ends non gracefully with no explicit error.

modules.name: err_stream_push_after_eof
modules.desc: An attempt was made to call stream.push() after a null(EOF) had been pushed to the stream.

modules.name: err_stream_unshift_after_end_event
modules.desc: An attempt was made to call stream.unshift() after the 'end' event was emitted.

modules.name: err_stream_wrap
modules.desc:
Prevents an abort if a string decoder was set on the Socket or if the decoder is in objectMode.

const Socket = require('net').Socket;
const instance = new Socket();

instance.setEncoding('utf8');

modules.name: err_stream_write_after_end
modules.desc: An attempt was made to call stream.write() after stream.end() has been called.

modules.name: err_string_too_long
modules.desc: An attempt has been made to create a string longer than the maximum allowed length.

modules.name: err_system_error
modules.desc: An unspecified or non-specific system error has occurred within the Node.js process. The error object will have an err.info object property with additional details.

modules.name: err_tls_cert_altname_invalid
modules.desc: While using TLS, the hostname/IP of the peer did not match any of the subjectAltNames in its certificate.

modules.name: err_tls_dh_param_size
modules.desc: While using TLS, the parameter offered for the Diffie-Hellman (DH) key-agreement protocol is too small. By default, the key length must be greater than or equal to 1024 bits to avoid vulnerabilities, even though it is strongly recommended to use 2048 bits or larger for stronger security.

modules.name: err_tls_handshake_timeout
modules.desc: A TLS/SSL handshake timed out. In this case, the server must also abort the connection.

modules.name: err_tls_renegotiate
modules.desc: An attempt to renegotiate the TLS session failed.

modules.name: err_tls_renegotiation_disabled
modules.desc: An attempt was made to renegotiate TLS on a socket instance with TLS disabled.

modules.name: err_tls_required_server_name
modules.desc: While using TLS, the server.addContext() method was called without providing a hostname in the first parameter.

modules.name: err_tls_session_attack
modules.desc: An excessive amount of TLS renegotiations is detected, which is a potential vector for denial-of-service attacks.

modules.name: err_tls_sni_from_server
modules.desc: An attempt was made to issue Server Name Indication from a TLS server-side socket, which is only valid from a client.

modules.name: err_trace_events_category_required
modules.desc: The trace_events.createTracing() method requires at least one trace event category.

modules.name: err_trace_events_unavailable
modules.desc: The trace_events module could not be loaded because Node.js was compiled with the --without-v8-platform flag.

modules.name: err_transferring_externalized_sharedarraybuffer
modules.desc:
A SharedArrayBuffer whose memory is not managed by the JavaScript engine or by Node.js was encountered during serialization. Such a SharedArrayBuffer cannot be serialized.

This can only happen when native addons create SharedArrayBuffers in "externalized" mode, or put existing SharedArrayBuffer into externalized mode.

modules.name: err_transform_already_transforming
modules.desc: A Transform stream finished while it was still transforming.

modules.name: err_transform_with_length_0
modules.desc: A Transform stream finished with data still in the write buffer.

modules.name: err_tty_init_failed
modules.desc: The initialization of a TTY failed due to a system error.

modules.name: err_uncaught_exception_capture_already_set
modules.desc:
process.setUncaughtExceptionCaptureCallback() was called twice, without first resetting the callback to null.

This error is designed to prevent accidentally overwriting a callback registered from another module.

modules.name: err_unescaped_characters
modules.desc: A string that contained unescaped characters was received.

modules.name: err_unhandled_error
modules.desc: An unhandled error occurred (for instance, when an 'error' event is emitted by an EventEmitter but an 'error' handler is not registered).

modules.name: err_unknown_builtin_module
modules.desc: Used to identify a specific kind of internal Node.js error that should not typically be triggered by user code. Instances of this error point to an internal bug within the Node.js binary itself.

modules.name: err_unknown_encoding
modules.desc: An invalid or unknown encoding option was passed to an API.

modules.name: err_unknown_file_extension
modules.desc: An attempt was made to load a module with an unknown or unsupported file extension.

modules.name: err_unknown_module_format
modules.desc: An attempt was made to load a module with an unknown or unsupported format.

modules.name: err_unknown_signal
modules.desc: An invalid or unknown process signal was passed to an API expecting a valid signal (such as subprocess.kill()).

modules.name: err_unknown_stdin_type
modules.desc: An attempt was made to launch a Node.js process with an unknown stdin file type. This error is usually an indication of a bug within Node.js itself, although it is possible for user code to trigger it.

modules.name: err_unknown_stream_type
modules.desc: An attempt was made to launch a Node.js process with an unknown stdout or stderr file type. This error is usually an indication of a bug within Node.js itself, although it is possible for user code to trigger it.

modules.name: err_v8breakiterator
modules.desc: The V8 BreakIterator API was used but the full ICU data set is not installed.

modules.name: err_valid_performance_entry_type
modules.desc: While using the Performance Timing API (perf_hooks), no valid performance entry types were found.

modules.name: err_vm_dynamic_import_callback_missing
modules.desc: A dynamic import callback was not specified.

modules.name: err_vm_module_already_linked
modules.desc:
The module attempted to be linked is not eligible for linking, because of one of the following reasons:

  • It has already been linked (linkingStatus is 'linked')
  • It is being linked (linkingStatus is 'linking')
  • Linking has failed for this module (linkingStatus is 'errored')

modules.name: err_vm_module_different_context
modules.desc: The module being returned from the linker function is from a different context than the parent module. Linked modules must share the same context.

modules.name: err_vm_module_linking_errored
modules.desc: The linker function returned a module for which linking has failed.

modules.name: err_vm_module_not_linked
modules.desc: The module must be successfully linked before instantiation.

modules.name: err_vm_module_not_module
modules.desc: The fulfilled value of a linking promise is not a vm.SourceTextModule object.

modules.name: err_vm_module_status
modules.desc: The current module's status does not allow for this operation. The specific meaning of the error depends on the specific function.

modules.name: err_worker_path
modules.desc: The path for the main script of a worker is neither an absolute path nor a relative path starting with ./ or ../.

modules.name: err_worker_unserializable_error
modules.desc: All attempts at serializing an uncaught exception from a worker thread failed.

modules.name: err_worker_unsupported_extension
modules.desc: The pathname used for the main script of a worker has an unknown file extension.

modules.name: err_zlib_initialization_failed
modules.desc: Creation of a zlib object failed due to incorrect configuration.

modules.name: hpe_header_overflow

changes.description: Max header size in `http_parser` was set to 8KB.

modules.desc: Too much HTTP header data was received. In order to protect against malicious or malconfigured clients, if more than 8KB of HTTP header data is received then HTTP parsing will abort without a request or response object being created, and an Error with this code will be emitted.

modules.name: module_not_found
modules.desc: A module file could not be resolved while attempting a require() or import operation.

miscs.name: legacy_node.js_error_codes
miscs.stabilityText:
Deprecated. These error codes are either inconsistent, or have
been removed.

modules.name: err_http2_frame_error
modules.desc: Used when a failure occurs sending an individual frame on the HTTP/2 session.

modules.name: err_http2_headers_object
modules.desc: Used when an HTTP/2 Headers Object is expected.

modules.name: err_http2_header_required
modules.desc: Used when a required header is missing in an HTTP/2 message.

modules.name: err_http2_info_headers_after_respond
modules.desc: HTTP/2 informational headers must only be sent prior to calling the Http2Stream.prototype.respond() method.

modules.name: err_http2_stream_closed
modules.desc: Used when an action has been performed on an HTTP/2 Stream that has already been closed.

modules.name: err_http_invalid_char
modules.desc: Used when an invalid character is found in an HTTP response status message (reason phrase).

modules.name: err_napi_cons_prototype_object
modules.desc: Used by the N-API when Constructor.prototype is not an object.

modules.name: err_outofmemory
modules.desc: Used generically to identify that an operation caused an out of memory condition.

modules.name: err_parse_history_data
modules.desc: The repl module was unable to parse data from the REPL history file.

modules.name: err_stderr_close

changes.description: Rather than emitting an error, `process.stderr.end()` now only closes the stream side but not the underlying resource, making this error obsolete.

modules.desc: An attempt was made to close the process.stderr stream. By design, Node.js does not allow stdout or stderr streams to be closed by user code.

modules.name: err_stdout_close

changes.description: Rather than emitting an error, `process.stderr.end()` now only closes the stream side but not the underlying resource, making this error obsolete.

modules.desc: An attempt was made to close the process.stdout stream. By design, Node.js does not allow stdout or stderr streams to be closed by user code.

modules.name: err_stream_read_not_implemented
modules.desc: Used when an attempt is made to use a readable stream that has not implemented readable._read().

modules.name: err_tls_renegotiation_failed
modules.desc: Used when a TLS renegotiation request has failed in a non-specific way.

modules.name: err_unknown_builtin_module
modules.desc: The 'ERR_UNKNOWN_BUILTIN_MODULE' error code is used to identify a specific kind of internal Node.js error that should not typically be triggered by user code. Instances of this error point to an internal bug within the Node.js binary itself.

modules.name: err_value_out_of_range
modules.desc: Used when a given value is out of the accepted range.

modules.name: err_zlib_binding_closed
modules.desc: Used when an attempt is made to use a zlib object after it has already been closed.

modules.name: other_error_codes
modules.desc: These errors have never been released, but had been present on master between releases.

modules.name: err_fs_watcher_already_started
modules.desc: An attempt was made to start a watcher returned by fs.watch() that has already been started.

modules.name: err_fs_watcher_not_started
modules.desc: An attempt was made to initiate operations on a watcher returned by fs.watch() that has not yet been started.

modules.name: err_http2_already_shutdown
modules.desc: Occurs with multiple attempts to shutdown an HTTP/2 session.

modules.name: err_http2_error
modules.desc: A non-specific HTTP/2 error has occurred.

modules.name: err_invalid_repl_history
modules.desc: Used in the repl in case the old history file is used and an error occurred while trying to read and parse it.

modules.name: err_missing_dynamic_instantiate_hook
modules.desc: Used when an ES6 module loader hook specifies format: 'dynamic' but does not provide a dynamicInstantiate hook.

modules.name: err_stream_has_stringdecoder
modules.desc:
Used to prevent an abort if a string decoder was set on the Socket.

const Socket = require('net').Socket;
const instance = new Socket();

instance.setEncoding('utf8');

modules.name: err_string_too_large
modules.desc: An attempt has been made to create a string larger than the maximum allowed size.

classes.name: Error
classes.desc:
A generic JavaScript Error object that does not denote any specific circumstance of why the error occurred. Error objects capture a "stack trace" detailing the point in the code at which the Error was instantiated, and may provide a text description of the error.

For crypto only, Error objects will include the OpenSSL error stack in a separate property called opensslErrorStack if it is available when the error is thrown.

All errors generated by Node.js, including all System and JavaScript errors, will either be instances of, or inherit from, the Error class.

methods.name: captureStackTrace
methods.desc:
Creates a .stack property on targetObject, which when accessed returns a string representing the location in the code at which Error.captureStackTrace() was called.

const myObject = {};
Error.captureStackTrace(myObject);
myObject.stack;  // similar to `new Error().stack`

The first line of the trace will be prefixed with ${myObject.name}: ${myObject.message}.

The optional constructorOpt argument accepts a function. If given, all frames above constructorOpt, including constructorOpt, will be omitted from the generated stack trace.

The constructorOpt argument is useful for hiding implementation details of error generation from an end user. For instance:

function MyError() {
  Error.captureStackTrace(this, MyError);
}

// Without passing MyError to captureStackTrace, the MyError
// frame would show up in the .stack property. By passing
// the constructor, we omit that frame, and retain all frames below it.
new MyError().stack;

properties.name: stackTraceLimit
properties.desc:
The Error.stackTraceLimit property specifies the number of stack frames collected by a stack trace (whether generated by new Error().stack or Error.captureStackTrace(obj)).

The default value is 10 but may be set to any valid JavaScript number. Changes will affect any stack trace captured after the value has been changed.

If set to a non-number value, or set to a negative number, stack traces will not capture any frames.

properties.name: code
properties.desc: The error.code property is a string label that identifies the kind of error. error.code is the most stable way to identify an error. It will only change between major versions of Node.js. In contrast, error.message strings may change between any versions of Node.js. See Node.js Error Codes for details about specific codes.

properties.name: message
properties.desc:
The error.message property is the string description of the error as set by calling new Error(message). The message passed to the constructor will also appear in the first line of the stack trace of the Error, however changing this property after the Error object is created may not change the first line of the stack trace (for example, when error.stack is read before this property is changed).

const err = new Error('The message');
console.error(err.message);
// Prints: The message

properties.name: stack
properties.desc:
The error.stack property is a string describing the point in the code at which the Error was instantiated.

Error: Things keep happening!
   at /home/gbusey/file.js:525:2
   at Frobnicator.refrobulate (/home/gbusey/business-logic.js:424:21)
   at Actor.<anonymous> (/home/gbusey/actors.js:400:8)
   at increaseSynergy (/home/gbusey/actors.js:701:6)

The first line is formatted as <error class name>: <error message>, and is followed by a series of stack frames (each line beginning with "at "). Each frame describes a call site within the code that lead to the error being generated. V8 attempts to display a name for each function (by variable name, function name, or object method name), but occasionally it will not be able to find a suitable name. If V8 cannot determine a name for the function, only location information will be displayed for that frame. Otherwise, the determined function name will be displayed with location information appended in parentheses.

Frames are only generated for JavaScript functions. If, for example, execution synchronously passes through a C++ addon function called cheetahify which itself calls a JavaScript function, the frame representing the cheetahify call will not be present in the stack traces:

const cheetahify = require('./native-binding.node');

function makeFaster() {
  // cheetahify *synchronously* calls speedy.
  cheetahify(function speedy() {
    throw new Error('oh no!');
  });
}

makeFaster();
// will throw:
//   /home/gbusey/file.js:6
//       throw new Error('oh no!');
//           ^
//   Error: oh no!
//       at speedy (/home/gbusey/file.js:6:11)
//       at makeFaster (/home/gbusey/file.js:5:3)
